description:
Gry Skomsoy Today at 7:28 AM
We have recently had several customers who have misunderstood our success center article: https://success.planview.com/Projectplace/Account_administration/Enable_and_manage_workspace_requests#Manage_Incoming_Requests
Especially the first sentence: Administrators view requests and choose to approve or reject them. If a request is approved, a project/activity/card is created in Projectplace.
When it comes to Card and activities this can only be forwarded to the Workspace, and only be approved by the head admin of the workspace.
Our users understands it as those who have Request admin rights should also be able to approve cards and avtivities.
It is correctly described under Create an Activity or Card from a Request.

```
cards_without_boards = [card.id for card in cards if not card.board()]

    with sql2.transaction() as tx:

            tx.execute(
                '''
                update ppcarddependencies set isvalid = false where
                cardid = :card_id or predecessorid = :card_id
                ''', {
                    'card_id': card_id
                }
            )
```

description:
Sorry, Swedish :-) 

1. Vi har ett separat “subrepo” eller en “submodule” till main_service för alla översättningsfiler(eller möjligen ett separat för mobile och ett för Webben). Detta bestämmer vi när vi gör det, spelar inte så stor roll för oss direkt.
2. Utvecklare lägger till id + “temporär översättning” i den engelska filen  --> Automatisk ping till en "PP översättnings" Slackkanal om "new id added for translation". Kanske sker pingen endast en gång per dag, eller direkt när det händer. Vi får väl se vad som känns rimligast.
3. Original ide:Utvecklare lägger till ett kort på översättningstavlan(som idag, där kan bild läggas till), med "release datum".\
    Vi beslutade att istället bara använda "PP översättnings” Slackkanalen för att kommunicera det som behöver kommuniceras och eventuella bilder för att förklara id:n vid behov.
4. Uppdatera filtyperna till JSON(förmodligen) för att kunna lägga till en beskrivning per id.

Frågor: Proofreading av engelskan, hur skall det går till? Detta kan Olle och eller Leila snacka med Elisabetta om för det är där det sker idag för de andra produkterna(LeanKit i iallafall).

description:
Update Board charts available from an individual Board and from the Workspace Overview
Review and update the graph library for the Board charts (Burn up, Burn down, Cycle time and Cumulative flow

description:
HTTPOnly cookies cannot be read by client-side scripts, therefore marking a cookie as HTTPOnly can provide an additional layer of protection against cross-site scripting attacks.

Impact
During a cross-site scripting attack, an attacker might easily access cookies and hijack the victim's session.

More info can be found in the report attached here: https://service.projectplace.com/pp/pp.cgi/r1989677980
title: Cookie Not Marked as HttpOnly

description:
Netsparker Enterprise detected a Robots.txt file with potentially sensitive content.
Impact
Depending on the content of the file, an attacker might discover hidden directories and files.

More info can be found in the report attached here: https://service.projectplace.com/pp/pp.cgi/r1989677980
title: Robots.txt Detected

description:
Netsparker Enterprise detected a missing X-Frame-Options header which means that this website could be at risk of a clickjacking attack.

The X-Frame-Options HTTP header field indicates a policy that specifies whether the browser should render the transmitted resource within a frame or an iframe. Servers can declare this policy in the header of their HTTP responses to prevent clickjacking attacks, which ensures that their content is not embedded into other pages or frames.

Impact
Clickjacking is when an attacker uses multiple transparent or opaque layers to trick a user into clicking on a button or link on a framed page when they were intending to click on the top level page. Thus, the attacker is "hijacking" clicks meant for their page and routing them to other another page, most likely owned by another application, domain, or both.

Using a similar technique, keystrokes can also be hijacked. With a carefully crafted combination of stylesheets, iframes, and text boxes, a user can be led to believe they are typing in the password to their email or bank account, but are instead typing into an invisible frame controlled by the attacker.

URL: https://sandbox-us.projectplace.com/
title: Missing X-Frame-Options Header

description:
Netsparker Enterprise detected that wildcard was used in domain portion of a CSP directive.

Impact
This means you trust all of the subdomains of this domain, if this is the case there is no impact.
title: Wildcard Detected in Domain Portion of Content Security Policy (CSP) Directive

description:
Netsparker Enterprise identified an internal server error.

The server responded with an HTTP status 500, indicating there is a server-side error. Reasons may vary, and the behavior should be analyzed carefully. If Netsparker Enterprise is able to find a security issue in the same resource, it will report this as a separate vulnerability.

Impact
The impact may vary depending on the condition. Generally this indicates poor coding practices, not enough error checking, sanitization and whitelisting. However, there might be a bigger issue, such as SQL injection. If that's the case, Netsparker Enterprise will check for other possible issues and report them separately.

More info can be found in the report attached here: https://service.projectplace.com/pp/pp.cgi/r1989677980
title: Internal Server Error

description:
Netsparker Enterprise identified a cookie not marked as secure, and transmitted over HTTPS.

This means the cookie could potentially be stolen by an attacker who can successfully intercept and decrypt the traffic, or following a successful man- in-the-middle attack.

Impact
This cookie will be transmitted over a HTTP connection, therefore if this cookie is important (such as a session cookie), an attacker might intercept it and hijack a victim's session. If the attacker can carry out a man-in-the-middle attack, he/she can force the victim to make an HTTP request to steal the cookie.

Identified Cookie(s)
_ga 
_gat

More info can be found in the report attached here: https://service.projectplace.com/pp/pp.cgi/r1989677980

description:
Web applications should cache non-sensitive client-side application code, styles, fonts, images, icons and pictures to increase performance, keep data physically closer to user, and avoid retransmission of the same data. However, other types of documents tend to collect or display sensitive information.

1. Information collected from users 
1. Information selected from a data store

In addition to browser caches, there are other machines on the path that cache

Web Proxies 
ISP Proxies 
Client Proxies

System that do not implement appropriate cache-control settings may leak data and be susceptible to Denial of Service (DOS) attacks. For web sites that only contain public data, the cache-control maintains the privacy of the user. In some cases, the fact that the user visited the site is itself sensitive information. Cache-control maintains the privacy of the user even when the data is not sensitive.

Remediation Link: https://wss.inside.ups.com/sites/CRA/WebSecurity/Web%20Application%20Best%20Practice%20and%20Vulnerability%20Re/Remediation%20Guide%20- %20How%20To%20Prevent%20Caching%20of%20Sensitive%20Data.aspx

IF Response.Content-Type IN [application/ecmascript, application/javascript, font/, image/, text/css] THEN Cache-Control: no-cache="Set-Cookie"; ELSE Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache Pragma: no-cache END IF
title: Cacheable Response

description:
The Customize list view modal is at the moment not conform to our Design system pattern. 
According to the pattern, the items that are hidden in the Customize modal should keep the same position on save.
In the current implementation though, the hidden items are moved to the bottom of the list on save.

This is because the backend returns 2 separate lists: one for visible columns and one for hidden columns. 
Ideally we would like to only have one list, so that items can keep their original position no matter if they are hidden or visible
title: Singe portfolio view - Change Customize list view behavior for hidden columns

description:
An unauthenticated user is able to query the teams API endpoint and observe the discrepancy in responses to perform enumeration activities for team identifiers. In the case of a valid ID, a 403 Forbidden response is returned, while an invalid ID request returns a 404 Not Found response. While an unauthenticated user cannot access team information that they do not have permissions to access, knowledge of valid team identifiers could be used in other attacks where authentication is broken. This attack was accomplished by issuing a GET request to the location path noted above and appending an 8 digit ID number (Figure 7). A control test was attempted with a random string to observe results of known invalid entry (Figure 8). 

Remediation:
Consistent and generic error messages should be returned to the unauthenticated user in all cases.
title: Unauthenticated Team ID Enumeration

Within the noted location path, enumeration attempts were made by changing the number appended at the end to a user set value (i.e. /pub/english.cgi/0/1, /pub/english.cgi/0/2, /pub/english.cgi/0/3, etc). While doing so, when applying “1” as the appended id number, an old interface is seemingly exposed. This could potentially expand the attack surface for a malicious actor or introduce further vulnerabilities into the environment. This was performed as an authenticated (Figure 12) and unauthenticated user (Figure 13).

Remediation:
Remove logic to display deprecated interfaces and ensure consistent error handling for unauthenticated users.
title: Deprecated Interface Exposed to Unauthenticated User

description:
The ability to send requests to other systems can allow vulnerable pages to be used as an attack proxy. With the right payload, an attacker can cause the application server to attack other systems that it can interact with. Depending on the network layout, this may expose internal services that are not otherwise accessible to external attackers. By manually changing the parameter in the True-Client-IP header, it is possible for malicious actors to spoof their IP address. This does not constitute a vulnerability by itself, but in certain situations, applications will use this to enforce access controls and rate limiting. This could be important if certain IP addresses are whitelisted or if each IP only gets a limited number of login attempts. It may prove beneficial to review the functionality to determine if this is the case.
In order to replicate this, intercept the packet with an intercepting proxy or craft the packet with curl and manually apply the True-Client-IP header to the desired IP address.

Remediation:
True-Client-IP is not a reliable way to enforce security measures (ex: access controls). If this is needed for security measures, it should be replaced with something more secure that is not vulnerable to spoofing.
Typically, if a server returns incorrect information about a client IP due to a header, then the server may need to be reconfigured or a different way to identify clients should be applied.
title: True-Client-IP Header External DNS interaction

description:
OSec observed several instances of insecure JavaScript coding practices within the client-side source code of the application that could lead to the execution of malicious input as trusted code in proprietary code written for the application. There were multiple uses of DOM element injection via the innerHTML function with no input validation. Additionally, there were methods that performed string concatenation from server responses or element attributes with no validation or special character neutralization as well. These strings were often injected as input to innerHTML.
OSec also observed instances of the eval function in use that can lead to the execution of string input as script logic and execute in the context of the user session.
OSec did not find a means to inject content into these instances without extensive code analysis, but was able to validate malicious input to a function would successfully execute JavaScript code on a modified object. This could be chained together as an attack vector for prototype pollution or user generated content.

Remediation:
Remove all instances of the eval function and write functions to execute static code. Remove all instances of innerHTML and use DOM element creation methods to inject new HTML elements into the DOM as well as perform input validation on functions that will modify the DOM via input parameters. Perform special character neutralization/sanitization when performing dynamic string creation and DOM injection.
Additionally, a hardened Content Security Policy would instruct the browser to disallow certain JavaScript behaviors such as the invocation of the eval function.
title: Insecure JavaScript Coding Practices

description:
OSec was able to verify that a CSRF vulnerability was present and exploitable in the user “Forgot Password” functionality. OSec was able to create a proof-of-concept of a malicious domain submitting a POST request on behalf of the current user with no restrictions in place to ensure the form was being submitted from the Projectplace application. A malicious actor could perform a UI redress attack in this instance by cloning the page on a malicious domain to collect valid email addresses of Projectplace users. This attack was accomplished by viewing and editing the source code within the noted location path and then submitting the request as normal.

Remediation:
Implement anti-CSRF tokens and server side protections into the “Forgot Password” page, consistent with other protected forms.
title: CSRF Vulnerability in Forgot Password Page
